column1: See https://github.com/jakecoppinger/heath-st-council-meeting-transcript for video source and more info.

column4: Raw transcription
So I'm going to move on with the other item that has speakers listed and that is the item on the
traffic committee of 10.1. So I suppose we should open the traffic committee.
Oh no we'll hear the public forum first then we can do it.
Yep okay this is to do with the cycleway in Heath Street so just if I call your name out
put your hand up so I know you're here. Ralph? Rula? Ralph?
David Martin? Yes. Francis O'Neill?
Michael? Mike? Mike Boonton is in? Thank you.
You're against? Ross Butler? Annie? Xerib? Annie you're from Mortlake are you speaking on this
Heath Street one are you? Yes we are.
Sorry Mr there's a lot of audible conversation it's hard to hear people speak.
If you need to speak anybody that's please we would like everybody to you know listen and
hear what's going on so if you need to speak the door's there go for it. Once in here please
respect the floor and the speakers.
Yeah so yeah we're only dealing with a little 200 meter section of the bikeway we're not dealing
with the whole lot. We're not going to speak about anything else because we've got a specific report
to do with Heath Street.
We're only going to speak about Heath Street tonight. We're not right and with Baybug if I
might just wish to ask you please it's a number of your speakers here tonight.
We'd love to hear everything you have to say but not three four five times so keep it nice and short
keep it to the issue and that's Heath Street and we all want to try to create a better
liveable area Canada Bay but we're not going to solve the whole problem of the cycleway
here tonight. We're only going to speak about Heath Street so once you start going off about
other cycleways we're going to stop you there. Only Heath Street tonight talking about 200 meters
and that's what we'll hear about so if you can please keep to that that would be great.
So we'll let you go on about it Heath Street but just don't keep repeating. So first speaker Ralph
I apologize. Please accept my apologies. I understand what you mean. My name's pretty hard to pronounce.
I've been Ralphed all my life. I'm a bit sensitive to it. Mr. Mayor and Councillor I'm speaking as a
representative of the Canada Bay Bicycle User Group and first of all let me acknowledge that
the concerns voiced by residents that led to the proposal to remove the cycleway are genuinely held
beliefs and that they should be taken seriously. Each concern must be thoroughly evaluated
in careful consideration be given to addressing them. To me council's proposal along with the
consultant report that attempts to support it does none of that and represents a knee-jerk reaction
to put the matter to bed in the most politically expedient way. As someone who uses my bike to
commute do the grocery shopping and travel around some of the wonderful destinations around Greater
Sydney I was very pleased last September to see what I believed to be the first section in Heath
Street of the taxpayer funded Canada Bay Regional Cycleway actually completed. I've written that
section by myself and with much less able riders in the 20 plus years before the cycleway was in
place and always felt like a sitting duck while grinding slowly up the hill. Nearby streets are
harder to climb or have more exposure to motor traffic. Heath Street with its combination of
lower traffic volumes and easier climb has always been the natural choice for those who cycle from
the Bayrun and Timberl Park towards Central Five Dock and beyond. I asked Professor Miad Saberi from
the University of New South Wales on the bike traffic modelling he has done and he said that
Heath Street accommodates between 94 and 100 to 185 cycling trips per weekday on average excluding
weekends that means between 23,500 and 46,250 cycling trips per year. Those estimates were based
on 2021 data. If you count in weekends the number is likely to exceed 50,000 trips per year. Those
were his words not mine. I was gobsmacked when I discovered a few months later the council now
proposes to remove what looked to me like a well thought out piece of infrastructure that finally
takes into account the safety of all road users. There are hundreds of kilometers of separated
cycleway throughout Sydney a significant proportion of which run through residential
streets like Heath Street and to my knowledge they have not led to an increase of risk or hazard
to any particular category of road user. In fact I understand the net effect has been to reduce
the number and severity of crashes in the neighborhoods where they are located.
So while trying to distill the gist of the Heath Street residents concerns it occurred to me that
the main issue was a sudden change to the streetscape and I acknowledge that that can be very distressing.
It must be stated that Heath Street is not the exclusive property of the residents that live there
nor the Timberl Park sports people that park there on weekends and weeknights and certainly
not the people who ride their bikes along there. Heath Street is there for all road users in New
South Wales to use. Like the Land Act says streets are provided for the movement of people.
When I bought my house in Corrie's Avenue 23 years ago I was never asked if I thought it was
okay for motor traffic to increase by a factor of three nor was I asked if it was okay for the
street to become so solidly parked out a lot of the time that I have to take much more care looking
out for traffic when I drive my car out of the driveway. Yet that's what's happened and unlike
the residents of Heath Street there was not one iota of consultation. Canada Bay's environmental
strategy from 2020 forecasts a population to increase from 79,000 in 2018 to 120,000 by 2036.
By my sums that's an increase of 52 percent in that time the strategy forecasts walking to increase
to 20 percent and cycling to increase to five percent by 2036. The way we are headed it seems
like those figures are way too ambitious while council has a track record they can be proud of
putting down walking and cycling tracks in uncontested spaces in places like parks and
foreshores they have great benefits for recreation. The same can't be said for making road space safe
for kids to ride their bikes to school or mums and dads to ride to work or to do the shopping.
For the strategic plan to have any chance of actually working active transport.
Ralph do you need more time your five minutes is up? About 30 seconds. I'll put it all in place.
I always have it declared. Thank you. Thank you. Where was I? For the strategic plan to have any
chance to actually work active transport must be taken seriously otherwise we'll be seeing 52 percent
more cars clogging our roads and taking up non-existent parking spaces. Finally I would
like to remind councillors the regional cycleway is not for people like me who you see are confidently
rising riding in traffic it's for those you don't see because they are justifiably scared to ride
their bikes on the road. I therefore ask council that the removal be deferred for a trial period
while specific concerns are investigated in partnership as offered by Transport for New
South Wales experts. Thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak tonight. Thank you Ralph.
Did Ralph bring you did he bring all the baby issues to the floor or do we need to hear another
another one okay all right David Martin please.
Thanks Mr Mayor, councillors, officers, ladies and gentlemen. I'll just reiterate that last point that
we are really seeing a lot of people who are not really interested in the
traffic and the safety of their vehicles. We want to see an improvement in streets in Canada Bay
for people walking for children for families for young people and that's what's happened with this
200 meters is we're getting people who wouldn't ride normally feeling safe that they're protected
from traffic. I'm a parent a grandparent, ex-primary school teacher and I've got a 25 year career
in transport including in road safety so I'm only saying that to give you a little bit of a
I'm only saying that to demonstrate I've got some understanding of the issues related to here so I'm
here to oppose the removal it's an excellent facility as Ralph says and we recognize that the
residents have got strongly held concerns but I think we can offer a constructive way forward.
I don't believe the evidence that's been put forward in the paper that's come to council with
the recommendation to remove it. I don't think the evidence really stacks up and I think the
significant thing we should note is the transport for New South Wales voted against the proposal to
remove it. They're the experts in this area and they've voted against it and if you go through the
I do. Transport technically and in terms of regional network and cycleways they've got a
whole lot of guidelines they've got the I don't want to go on but yes of course they are.
So there are six pages and they go through here if you've read the agenda item the six pages you'll
see that they're refuting each of the points and I'll just make some of those look and the broader
point is that the impetus for the removal of the cycleway comes from the fact that circumstances
in the streets in the lovely area of Rudd Point have changed and people are having trouble adapting
to it and they've got very upset. Some of the points the key points that have been raised in
opposition is the reduced width of Heath Street it's with the cycleway from those concrete buffers
to the curb 8.859 meters and they're saying oh you know they could be head-on collisions.
Well my street in Fyfe Duc where I live it's 6.6 meters and the difference is something like that
so transport says that it's not a problem it's very generous with compared with streets around
Will Sydney and Fyfe Duc and in Rod Point too it's a very wide street
we've coped with it in my street there are no head-ons
people it's called the Yield Street if cars are coming together one must give way to the other
you've got to duck in that's the way it works it's not that hard. Sight lines drivers leaving driveways
yes it's it's changed transport says they've got to check for bicycles as they come out of their
properties then go past the parked cars and check for traffic you've got to creep out that's the way
you do it this is Sydney there's a lot of traffic there's a lot of um there's need to be careful
things are changing. Heath and Rickard we need to investigate it because they're talking about the
sight lines you may need to move the give way line you might need to put in some concrete curve
extensions transport says it's it's fixable in fact all the problems that are raised
can be fixed by it's transport management 101 the other thing too is is community engagement
what we've done what council's done with this with the community consultation is invite everybody
to throw in all their bits and pieces about what they like or don't like what's really
going to happen now is the community's got to be engaged one-on-one if they see problems
that they'd like to see resolved so it's a different model okay so there may be tweaks required
to the concrete separators to you might need to get a driving instructor in to coach people
about driving in and out that has happened that has happened in other places you've really got to
you've really got to help people adapt to change the uh the external traffic engineer says remove
the cycle way to be safer for all road users absolutely no consideration in that report
of the safety of bicycle users and that separation uh gives and taking it out is going to deter
people from riding bikes the officer's report fails to note that the majority of respondents
to the community consultation oppose a removal this is really about the interest of a small group
of agitated residents over the benefits of everybody else in canada bay might also draw
attention to financial matters ripping it out council's going to have to pay for it
uh and it may result in financial penalties from the state authorities and place future
funding in jeopardy the state and federal fund funding sources really support much of the traffic
management that we're introducing like the wombats and the refuges around the streets we can
congratulate the council for getting that money because those funds are there but the waste is
not a good look not a good look do you need extra time yes one minute please
one minute all those in favor say aye say no no no i'm going please thank you okay
so the way the waste is not a good look for council after concord oval and all the other issues that
we've had um and i think the problems that it introduces with state funding is um is really
we can avoid it we can avoid it um so transport for new south wales is often a problem and we
we're not going to be able to do that so transport for new south wales is offering a joint reveal of
the design to balance all user requirements and all user safety issues and we support council
accepting that offer so i urge council is to frame a motion i ask that you frame a motion
you've got to reject the recommendation from traffic committee and that'll be terrific or
defer the decision pending the development in conjunction with transport for new south wales
and the history that balances all user requirements and all user safety issues thank you thank you
very much thank you miss martin can i ask for the next speaker please francis o'neill
evening everyone um this will be short uh i'm francis o'neill from bicycle new south wales
uh peak body for active transport i want to thank canada bay council for the opportunity to support
the excellent cycleway that's on the heath street when i rode it i thought wow you know this is
generously wide it's wonderful um future planning sustainability active travel the distance between
the school the oval we're all about getting kids and old people from eight to eighty riding and
active the cycleway improves safety for vulnerable road users by being separated it therefore
encourages the 48 interested but concerned people to take up bike riding road paint will never
achieve this outcome um heath street's safe convenient direct it's attractive to use uh this
is why after only four months the strava bike count is pretty high that was something ralph
mentioned encouraging active transport to reduce congestion reach net zero and improve our health
is why the heath street cycleway was built it's why we've got active transport plans sustainability
future proofing etc okay yeah i won't be long stick to history yep yep this is heath street
it's related because on the basis of those plans canada bay council demonstrated its commitment to
active transport sustainability net zero and received seven million dollars new south wales
government funding in good faith in good faith the last traffic committee minutes noted that
heath street remains the most appropriate and strategic cycleway route along the paramounted
to cbd corridor that's why it got the funding the last minutes also noted transport for new south
wales has offered to review and improve the concept design as have bicycle new south wales
as has canada bay bugs okay i'm almost finished we disagree however with the previous minutes
noting that the removal of the cycleway will incur no additional cost okay firstly on two points
canada bay is likely to be asked by transport for new south wales to refund the portion or all of
the destroyed infrastructure spent secondly destruction of stage one risks the integrity
of the whole seven million dollar project in all its six stages the other financial implication is
that canada bay will be reviewed as an unreliable business partner for the many future transport
for new south wales active transport projects in the pipeline this cycleway is only four months old
and already doing so well so it lets everybody take a deep breath yeah just as it takes time to
create something so it creates it takes a bit of time to destroy it time is your friend canada bay
council time is your friend both sides agree this is where both sides agree consultation wasn't
done right yeah okay so let's use the time wisely before you just rip it out because you might get
it wrong you never know it is best practice on projects like this to bring the community
on board through a process of co-design whereby stakeholders learn about the many benefits
they get to air their concerns and get to shape the outcome it's advisable to consult with experts
on co-design to ensure success because that runs on the board i have outlined some of the reputational
and financial costs of trashing great infrastructure such as the heath street cycleway another cost is
is that canada bay will gain a reputation of being a walkover among the anti-cycleway lobby
making active transport projects that much harder to deliver you're creating a rod for your own back
by making this decision so take some time think it through finally let's remember public roads
are public roads and not the private property of residents who happen to live along them
they are for the benefit of all road users
um so again um a bit disappointed on you know bicycle new south wales taking that approach
about canada bay mike bottle please uh president of baybug thank you
good evening sir mayor councillors ladies and gentlemen thank you for the opportunity
um as president of baybug i'm the elected representative our local area um bicycle users
these are bicycle users of all ages their children cycling to school and local parks
in mothers and fathers often with toddler seats attached and they're some of our senior citizens
possibly with the electrical assistance to their bikes to help their mobility their commuters
and their leisure riders many if not most of these bicycle users do not feel safe riding on our
public roads i can say this with confidence because i'm in my role as president over the last five
years i've met over 100 members who often express these concerns not only for themselves but for
their spouses for their children and their parents all bicycle users under the law have the right to
use our public roads we all understand the responsibility of our authorities to provide
a safe road system for our motorists it's time that the same energy and expertise was put into
designing safe access routes for bicycle users the separated cycleway the 200 meter uphill stretch
in heath street provides that safe environment and marks a welcoming beginning to a shift in
design thinking in canada bay and aligns us with progressive councils that have rolled out kilometers
of separated cycleways to remove it and force riders to climb that hill at low speed potentially
with impatient drivers behind them is to create a much more dangerous environment a view that is
supported by transport for new south wales as ministered in the traffic committee meetings
the recommendation by council officers to remove the separated cycleway was driven i believe by
objections from residents of heat street understandable objections given the changes but
and this prompted council to commission an independent report known as the mcclaren report
for a brief period that report was available for viewing on the collaborate canada bay site and in
reading it i failed to see any obvious connection from the data and observations noted to how the
conclusions were reached i was particularly astonished by the summary which states and i
quote the resultant works meaning the construction of the separated cycleway have generally reduced
the safety of all users for all movements along along across and access via heat street end of
quote surely no one could argue that the separated cycleway has reduced the safety
of bicycle users compared to the alternative of riding on the road
i've lived in first avenue some 30 meters from the corner of um heat street for 32 years and as a
resident of first avenue i've welcomed the recent changes that have had significant calming effect
on motor traffic vehicles and namely the speed humps and the raised crossing at heat street
and which i'm sure the locals know like many of the residents of heat street who are claiming
that it's more difficult now to back out of their driveways i too have to use extreme caution when
backing into first avenue from my driveway the new traffic calming devices have improved that
situation their speeds are now noticeably reduced in first avenue this too will surely be the effect
in heat street as motorists become more accustomed to the narrowing and reduce their speed accordingly
council has already acknowledged that speeds have reduced from an average of 48 kilometers an hour
in heat street before the cycleway went in to now 44 kilometers as for the objection that the street
is now too narrow to back into safely and an opinion supported by the mclaren report i ask
by what measure even with the adjusted widths after construction of the separated cycleway the
carriageway curb to curb distance of heat street is between 9.05 and 9.1 meters i've measured this
with the exception of arthur street which is a busy through road i've measured all the other
parallel streets in rod point and found they're all under eight meters more than a meter narrower
than heath street so by what measure is it unsafe for heat street as it now conforms to the suburb
norm in summary i ask that council move to defer the traffic committee recommendation to remove
the cycleway pending a design review offered by transport for new south wales representative on
the traffic committee and council's own traffic studies and the expressed intention to look at
further traffic calming finally i ask all councillors here present to demonstrate their
commitment to creating a safe safer streets for all users and to encourage active transport and a
reduction in reliance on cars thereby reducing emissions by voting against the removal of the
separated cycleway thank you thank you mr potten uh ross i want to ask you to come up yet because
there's another speaker for the bay bugs i'll keep them in line so uh could i have angsirra please
come up and address the council
good evening mr mayor councillors my name is ann schwirb and i'm representing the peninsula's
action group we are community advocate group and we work with council on a range of local concerns
including transport traffic pedestrian safety and safety and safety and safety and safety and safety
and safety and safety and safety and safety and safety and safety and safety and safety and safety
matters here today each council's action group consists of five Agenda 9
if it was approved, will essentially dismember the Council's proposed
corridor of active transport access that feeds directly into our peninsula
communities and on to the farthest reaches of the LGA. The following are
just a few of Council's plans and guidelines that rely on the retention of
the Heath Street cycleway component as part of the overarching active transport
strategy for the whole of the Canada Bay LGA. Document 1 is the City of Canada Bay
Local Planning Strategy 2010-31 and we quote directly from that
document which proposes the delivery of a new regional cycleway that connects
western and eastern parts of the LGA and further the delivery of a
regional bike route that links Sydney City and Sydney Olympic Park across the
Canada Bay LGA. The second document that we refer to is the City of Sydney Canada
Bay Bike Plan 2020 available on Council's website which states to develop in
detail a core spinal cycleway network throughout the Canada Bay LGA and it
goes on to say perhaps most importantly to enable people to cycle safely.
Following the recent completion of the fantastic redevelopment of Concord Oval
the proposed removal of the Heath Street cycleway link would mean many local
families including children wishing to use active transport to attend this
world-class venue would have no way of doing so safely. This brings us to refer
to document 3 on Council's website which is the Concord Oval Precinct Management
Plan which recommends within the document the development of cycleway
connections to Concord Oval. Now there's the matter of the appropriate government
use of government funding. The government funding for local infrastructure
projects are generous gifts that benefit the whole of the Canada Bay community.
These grants assist councils such as ours to achieve its vision for the
amenity of local communities without the need to place additional
financial burdens on local ratepayers. Crucially at this time when Council is
proposing to raise council rates substantially. To now propose to rip up
this frequently used and funded completed infrastructure we believe
would certainly give the government as the President of Baybug has
alluded to it would give the government pause when considering future grants for
our LGA. This is even more important when we are aware that Transport for New South
Wales has very very strenuously opposed the destruction of this infrastructure.
We would now ask that because this proposed action to rip up a brand new
cycleway would this be at ratepayer cost? Is this the most appropriate use of
ratepayer money? The Peninsulas Action Group have serious concerns that if
approved the destruction of in situ infrastructure will create a precedent
alluded to by the President of Bicycle New South Wales that would jeopardize
future delivery of infrastructure programs of work designed to
benefit the whole of Canada Bay Council community. As we've pointed out above the
proposed removal of the Heath Street cycleway link is in direct contradiction
to Council's well documented strategy for active transport for our local
communities and any proposed removal of this link must be considered
holistically and not in isolation due to the ripple effects it could have the
removal could have on the very future of active transport across the LGA. Finally
we would ask that you please please put the safety and amenity of all
constituents front of mind when considering this proposal for destruction
of crucial funded completed and importantly embraced in situ
infrastructure when we ask that you please do not approve this proposal.
Thank you.
Thank you. Next speaker Ross Butler please.
Good evening Mayor and Councillors. Thank you for the opportunity to come here this evening to talk about
Heath Street and Heath Street alone. If John's still here I'd like to just
recognize that I'm probably one of those retirees John. Okay I'm here this evening
and I believe I represent the overwhelming opinion of residents in and
around Heath Street Rod Point to support the 16th of March Council's Local
Traffic Committee meeting recommendation that the separated cycleway in Heath
Street be removed and replaced with a two-way mixed traffic arrangement set
out in the Council's draft design modification proposal on 23rd January 2023.
There seems to be some confusion here tonight about the cycleway going away
from Heath Street. The cycleway is not going away from Heath Street. The cycleway
is going to remain in Heath Street. What is going to be removed is the cycle
pathway and the concrete blocks in the middle of the road. In addition to
be explained I'm requesting that Councillors consider further modifications
that not only respond to residents concerns but are common-sense changes
that make the cycleway more practical and provide workable arrangements to
residents living in and around Heath Street. The routing of the East West
cycleway by Heath Street has been the cause of great concern to residents
living in and around Heath Street. Their concerns have to do with
safety, the well-being of pedestrian cyclists and motorists, social harmony and
resident amenity. There is evidence and many well-formed arguments as to why
Heath Street is an inappropriate choice of a cycleway. It has been demonstrated
that this has resulted from non-existing research, poor planning,
limited implementation and a significant lack of community consultation.
However in the hope that there has been learning from the errors of the past and
in the spirit of goodwill is time to put these events behind us and to
make the most of the circumstances that are before us and to ensure that the
usage of Heath Street and the accompanying infrastructure is best fit
for purpose and that resident concerns are addressed in the most effective and
practical ways. It's been said before residents are the subject matter experts.
That is my neighbors and I in and around Heath Street are cognizant of activities
in in Heath Street and surrounding streets in terms of the uses of the
streets, about traffic movements, about the good and the bad and about how the
overall area functions.
We observe as we go about our daily lives people going for walks, exercising
their dogs, mothers with prams, how many cyclists use a cycleway, traffic at its
heaviest and at its lightest, when and how vehicles have difficulty to navigate
the island refuges, when cars are speeding, when people practice golf or
fly drones in Timberlake Park, what the impact on the area is when Timberlake
Park is in heavy use and when there are other
activities and incidents acceptable or not take place throughout the day and
night. With all due respect to council employees, cyclists and those who live
away from the area, they cannot fully appreciate and comprehend the whole
picture of Heath Street and the surrounding area. Reference to
Google Maps, spot visits or a 30 second cycle traverse through the area
only provides a snapshot and a possible distorted view. Hence the warranted
distress, outrage and sense of disrespect that residents have felt as they were
not appropriately consulted in relation to usage of Heath Street for the cycleway.
For example, it's now become obvious to everybody that those who decide that
Heath Street was an appropriate route for the cycleway had no idea of what
happens in terms of parking and motorist behavior when there is a significant
sporting event in Timberlake Park. If the planners of the cycleway had an inkling
of what occurs at those times, Heath Street would have been immediately
ruled out. Councillors De Pasquay, Little and Megner all have witnessed the chaos
to which I'm referring along with the new director, some of his staff and the
former acting director. Before moving to the further modifications that I
will request, I wish to acknowledge the involvement and interest of the mayor and
councillors in the concerns of residents and the willingness of the
new director and former acting director to listen and absorb resident feedback
that has been fed into the proposal, proposed modifications recommended by
the local traffic committee. Further, it was a welcome move by council engaging
the professional experts. Mr Butler, I'm nearly finished, I'll give you an extension.
Could I have an extension? No, put it in the move in a second and I'll put it all those
in the face, say aye. The ayes have it. Engaging the professional, engaging the
professional experts, McLaren traffic engineering who identified and confirmed
the residents fears relating to safety in Heath Street that has prompted the now
proposed modifications. Also, residents are awaiting the Timbrel Park parking
and pedestrian study. This leads me to the matters to which I request
councillors give further consideration. The issue of the availability of
parking brought into focus by implementation of the cycleway has not
been satisfactorily resolved and it appears it will continue to be a
significant inconvenience and source of anxiety for residents in Heath Street
and nearby. Currently the cycleway features island refuges in Heath Street
Henley Marine Drive that many have described as gross over-engineering and
a very clumsy solution to the impracticability of routing the cycleway
via Heath Street and Timbrel Park. These refuges have brought about the removal
of a number of parking spots creating parking pressure that becomes all too
obvious when there's a sporting events or other activities in Timbrel Park or
people are parked so as to complete a circuit of the bay run. In addition,
residents who have lived in the area for many years can no longer freely park
their cars close to their properties as has been their habit without risking
penalty resulting in a situation often where there's no available parking spaces
in close proximity. It is claimed by council that the refuges islands are in the
necessary safety feature of the cycleway and they may well be that if they were
used. For cyclists the refuges represent a roundabout means to traverse from
Heath Street across Henley Marine Drive and vice versa. While for pedestrians
there has never been and there still isn't any difficulty to cross safely
either Heath Street or Henley Marine Drive. Any casual observation verifies
that cyclists do not use the refuges travelling either north or south and
pedestrians will cross the roads as they please and not divert their journey to
use the refuge islands. At the moment it appears an intent of the refuge
islands to remain on the very speculative belief that cyclists and
pedestrians will use them in due course without any evidence to support that
supposition. Meanwhile local residents will continue to be unnecessarily
deprived of a degree of convenience for their daily lives and potentially the
islands will be in place virtually forever never been used. So my request to
councils to address the significant parking problems that exist in Heath
Street and surrounding areas is the refuge islands being removed. Should the
cycleway using Heath Street actually ever attract critical mass which many doubt
then perhaps a need may arise for some reassessment. Council is further
requested to consider that certain areas be made available for resident parking
only to affect some balance in the uses of the diminished availability of on
street parking. The fact that council has a commissioned a specific study to look
at parking and pedestrians in the context of Tintrell Park demonstrates
that resident concerns in relation to parking have been recognized as genuine
and substantial. Removal of the island refuges and and or dedicated resident
parking spaces are practical and realistic solutions to a situation that
has developed over time exacerbated and emphasized by the by the cycleway in
Heath Street. I'm looking for your support councils and thanks for the time.
Thank you. And I think that that you referred to a traffic and pedestrian
study that is occurring also a plan of management for Tintrell Park so they all
into we've together to consider the options that may improve the parking and
speeding and so forth the around that area but thank you Mr. Butler can I ask
Maria Capesio to come up please. Thank you Mr. Mayor and councillors I don't have a
fancy speech that most of these people have written I'm just here representing
the residents of Heath Street because I am a resident of the street that has
been severely impacted since the cycleway has been implemented. I do
firstly want to stress that the residents are not anti cyclists we are
not anti cycleways we just want a safer environment for everybody residents the
cyclists motorists and since the implementation of the cycleway in our
street it has become extremely unsafe with already a cyclist landing on a car
we've already had that accident we have had close calls where my children have
almost been hit by vehicles traveling up Heath Street we have had elderly
residents who have been exiting their vehicles and tripping over the concrete
bollards in that street and damaging and you know getting severe injuries from
that what we want to see is a more safer street for everybody that's there now
since the implementation and you know cyclists don't understand what the
struggles are for us every day because they are not there every day day in day
out leaving the street multiple times a day like myself and like several other
residents prior to the cycleway being implemented we didn't have any problems
there was no issues we didn't write into the council to say hey you know I can't
get out of my driveway or there wasn't any cycling accidents at all but since
the implementation where there have been several difficulties that are
concerning mainly safety now when exiting my driveway for example I can see
the cyclists coming up but once I pass that small strip of road I am blind and
yesterday I almost hit a cyclist who was coming down Heath Street because I could
not see him at all prior to the cycleway I had plenty of room where I could see
because the cars are parked along the curb now cars are parked virtually like
